comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
You poor lonely thing out there!

Helllooooooo...

But of course you are just a handle for a very big lid.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] Ha ha! Centennial Park Reservoir No.1 (covered) (WS0022), completed 1898. The Australian Town and Country Journal of 22/10/1898 p.10 has a photo taken a few metres to the left of this image at the same time, judging from the vegetation etc. - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/71319284 . The pavilion is gone; just a brick entrance is there. See more details on the Sydney Water heritage site, which is not at all accurate in details, compared to contemporary newspaper articles.

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content: Much to ornate a handle to grip, lets try that again with a more agricultural design. www.sydneywater.com.au/Sustainability/OurHeritageAssets/_...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/highranger] Yes, away with Victorian frippery!  The Sydney Water site mentions that - "Circa 1930, the Tennis Pavilion [there were tennis courts on top of the reservoir for a while], designed by architect Howard Jouriand, was relocated to Lane Cove National Park and it remained there until c.1955."

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] The Victorian one was much nicer, but I guess it succombed to rust. 

The Department of Victorian Preservation was out voted by the Department of Myopia. I wonder if their grandchildren followed in their footsteps and used the same the long term principles toward the inspiration behind the Darling Harbour re-development.

;-)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: But wait - there's a close-up ... Which shows that the brick "agricultural design" access chamber was there all along, underneath the Victorian frippery - "Pavilion at Centennial Park, Sydney (NSW)" - State Records NSW 4481_a026_000246

comment.author: 86916510@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Good find Ace Ventura!
Maybe the Exhibition Centre has a heart afterall?  Haha

I must look for my photos of the railway shed which preceeded the exhibition site.
I do know they showed no frip nor fripperyness.

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: There used to be a large shelter with a fancy brick roof  near Fullers Bridge,  on the east side,   in the gully coming down from Roseville  and detached from the main sections of the park.     It had a fancy tile roof,  but not quite as fancy as this one.   It was there until the early 1970's.   Possibly the same one,  with the 4 small belfries removed.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Just to balance up the newspaper reports, here's an item which appeared in the Sydney Mail in December 1897 - news.google.com/newspapers?id=FvlPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JZUDA...
